title: How to Tie a Tie: The Four-in-Hand Knot
description: Learn to tie the classic and versatile Four-in-Hand knot, one of the simplest and most popular tie knots. Perfect for beginners, this knot creates a slender, slightly asymmetrical look suitable for most occasions and collar types.

steps.title: Drape and Position the Tie
steps.description: Stand in front of a mirror with your shirt collar turned up. Drape the tie around your neck, underneath the collar. The wide end of the tie should hang on your dominant side (e.g., your right side if you are right-handed), and the narrow end on the other. Adjust the tie so the wide end hangs about 12 inches (30 cm) lower than the narrow end. The seam of the tie should be facing your shirt.
tips: The tip of the wide end will determine the final length of your tie, so starting it significantly lower is crucial. A good starting point is to have the tip of the narrow end near your navel.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic instructional photo. A close-up, chest-level shot from the front of a man in his 30s wearing a crisp white collared shirt, with the collar up. He is draping a navy blue silk tie around his neck. The wide end on his right hangs significantly lower than the narrow end on his left. His hands are gently positioning the tie. The background is a softly blurred, well-lit bedroom. The lighting is soft and natural, coming from a side window, highlighting the texture of the tie.

steps.title: Cross the Wide End Over
steps.description: Take the wide end of the tie and cross it over the top of the narrow end, moving it towards your non-dominant side. The wide end should now be on the opposite side from where it started. Hold the crossover point with your non-dominant thumb and index finger to keep it secure against your chest.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic instructional photo, maintaining the same style. A close-up, chest-level shot from the front. The man is crossing the wide end of the navy blue tie over the narrow end. His right hand guides the wide end to the left, while his left index finger and thumb pinch the intersection of the two ends just below his chin. Sharp focus on the hands and the initial cross of the tie. Soft, natural side lighting.

steps.title: Bring the Wide End Under
steps.description: Continue holding the crossover point. Now, bring the wide end of the tie underneath the narrow end, moving it back towards your dominant side. The wide end should now be back where it started, with its seam facing outwards.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic instructional photo, same style. A close-up, chest-level shot. The man is wrapping the wide end of the tie underneath the narrow end. His right hand is guiding the wide end from left to right, passing it under the narrow end. The seam of the wide end is now visible. His left hand still holds the knot in place. Sharp focus on the movement. Soft, natural side lighting.

steps.title: Cross Over the Front Again
steps.description: Bring the wide end back over the top of the knot one more time, moving it from your dominant to your non-dominant side. This creates the front loop of the knot you will eventually pass the tie through. The wide end should now be on your non-dominant side again, with its front side facing out.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic instructional photo, same style. A close-up, chest-level shot. The man is bringing the wide end of the tie back across the front of the knot, from right to left. This action forms a clean horizontal band across the knot. His right hand guides the tie, and his left hand supports the forming knot. Soft, natural side lighting.

steps.title: Pass Up Through the Neck Loop
steps.description: Now, pass the wide end of the tie upwards through the loop that has formed around your neck. Guide the tip of the wide end up between your collar and the tie knot, emerging from behind the knot.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic instructional photo, same style. A close-up, chest-level shot. The man is feeding the wide end of the tie upwards, through the space between the knot and his neck. His right index finger is guiding the tip of the tie up and out from behind the knot. The motion is clear and precise. Soft, natural side lighting.

steps.title: Pass Down Through the Front Loop
steps.description: You should now see the front loop you created in Step 4. Carefully pass the wide end of the tie down through this front loop. Pull the wide end all the way through, but do not pull it tight yet.
tips: Use your index finger to slightly open the front loop, making it easier to thread the wide end through without twisting it.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic instructional photo, same style. A close-up, chest-level shot. The wide end of the tie, having come up through the neck loop, is now being threaded down through the front horizontal loop of the knot. The man's right index finger is holding the loop open as his left hand guides the tie's tip downwards. The focus is on the action of tucking the tie into the knot. Soft, natural side lighting.

steps.title: Tighten and Adjust
steps.description: To tighten the knot, hold the narrow end of the tie with one hand and gently slide the knot up towards your collar with the other hand. Adjust until the knot is snug but not constricting. The tip of the wide end should end at or just above your belt buckle. Once satisfied, flip down your collar and center the knot.
tips: To create a classic 'dimple' just below the knot, press your index finger into the center of the tie just below the knot as you perform the final tightening. Pinch the sides of the tie around your finger to set the dimple.
The narrow end can be tucked into the keeper loop on the back of the wide end to keep it hidden and neat.
warnings: Do not overtighten the tie. You should be able to fit one or two fingers comfortably between the tie and your neck.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic instructional photo, same style. A final chest-level shot. The man has a perfectly tied Four-in-Hand knot, snug against his now-folded-down white shirt collar. One hand is holding the narrow end of the tie, while the other is gently sliding the knot up to his neck for the final adjustment. The tie has a subtle dimple just below the knot. The tip of the wide end is positioned perfectly at his belt line. He looks satisfied. Soft, natural side lighting.

safety_notes: Ensure the tie is not so tight that it restricts breathing or blood circulation to your head. A properly tightened tie allows for comfortable movement and breathing throughout the day.
